description: Easy - Urban Crisis, Patronage, and Food Supply

questions.question: What system did displaced urban poor rely on for survival in Rome?
options: Government employment in construction and public works projects
Manufacturing jobs in textile and pottery production controlled by the state
The patronage system (clientela), where wealthy patrons provided necessities in exchange for political loyalty
Wages from agricultural work in gardens and orchards within the city
questions.text_reference: Section 5 - Dependency on Patrons and the Patronage System

questions.question: What was the clientela system?
options: A military recruitment system that drafted young men into the Roman legions
A trade association that regulated prices and working conditions for merchants
A patronage arrangement where patrons gave assistance to clients in exchange for political support
A legal framework that protected enslaved workers and guaranteed their eventual freedom
questions.text_reference: Section 5 - Dependency on Patrons and the Patronage System

questions.question: How was Rome's situation different from Athens regarding urban populations?
options: Rome's urban poor were all enslaved, while Athens's were free citizens
Athens never developed an urban dependent population despite being a city-state
Rome rejected patronage systems while Athens relied entirely on them for governance
Athens's founding mythology accommodated urban dependency, but Rome's ideal was the independent farmer
questions.text_reference: Section 5 - Comparison to Greece: Why Rome's Crisis Was Different

questions.question: Why did Italy and Rome depend on imported grain despite having rich agricultural land?
options: Roman farmers refused to grow grain and preferred other crops exclusively
Most agricultural production was concentrated in export-oriented latifundia controlled by wealthy owners
Italy's climate had changed making it unsuitable for grain production
Rome had conquered all grain-producing regions and redirected production away from Italy

questions.question: What was Rome's estimated urban population by the 2nd century BCE?
options: Around 200,000 people
Approximately 350,000 people
Over 500,000 people
Nearly 1 million people

questions.question: Who held the most influence over Tiberius and Gaius Gracchus's political thinking?
options: Their father, Tiberius Gracchus the Elder, through military command experience
Prominent Senate members who mentored them in traditional aristocratic politics
Their mother Cornelia, who provided advanced education and political engagement
Greek philosophers who visited Rome and taught them reformist ideas

questions.question: What was ager publicus?
options: Privately owned land that was taxed by the government as public revenue
Land conquered by Rome that technically belonged to the Roman state and could be distributed to citizens
Agricultural land reserved exclusively for military training and exercises
Territory controlled by Italian allies rather than direct Roman administration
questions.text_reference: Section 8 - The Legal Basis: Ager Publicus

questions.question: What office did Tiberius Gracchus hold when he proposed land reform?
options: Senator representing his aristocratic family in the Senate
Praetor with authority over the justice system and enforcement
Tribune of the people (tribunus plebis) elected to represent citizens' interests
Consul with executive authority over the entire Republic

questions.question: What unprecedented action did Tiberius take to overcome Senate obstruction?
options: He led an armed revolt and seized control of the Senate building forcefully
He proposed that the plebs vote to remove the tribune Octavius who was blocking his reforms
He convinced the military to march on Rome and enforce his legislative agenda
He formed an alliance with wealthy merchants to overthrow the Senate's authority

questions.question: How did Tiberius Gracchus die?
options: He was executed by legal order after a trial for treason against the state
He was assassinated along with supporters by senators who viewed him as a threat to their power
He died of illness while in exile after being forced to leave Rome
He was killed in battle while attempting to defend his reforms militarily
questions.text_reference: Section 8 - Tiberius's Attempts to Consolidate Power and His Death
